channel.title: Sound quality question to Auxy EDMers, FBers, Bassheads, etc…
channel.description:
How close is it possible to get to the sound presence of a track like this…?
https://soundcloud.com/nocopyrightsounds/clarx-zig-zag-ncs-release
I don't mean the actual sounds, but the mastering feel, the sound presence, saturation, compression, …
  Auxy is regarded as best-suited to EDM, FB, etc…. It also has built-in (auto)-'mastering'. But, I've never heard an Auxy track sound like tracks you hear in the EDM charts.
Is it possible to create something entirely in Auxy that has the same in-your-face feel and presence as (e.g.) the Clarx track?
  <small>(Note: I'm not a fan of those genres. I'm just curious how close Auxy can get to sounding like that, supposedly the genre it's best-suited to. It ties in with questions I have about whether Auxy's auto-mastering is sufficient for making truly release-ready, competitive tracks.)</small>

item.title: Sound quality question to Auxy EDMers, FBers, Bassheads, etc…

item.description:
yeah, i was just pointing out what GB already had, don’t have to port the whole thing over lol

item.source: Sound quality question to Auxy EDMers, FBers, Bassheads, etc…

item.title: Sound quality question to Auxy EDMers, FBers, Bassheads, etc…
item.dc:creator: TheRealJFalc
item.description:
El1011:

All in all, Auxy should implement a master/processing channel, even a basic one like the GB with high,med,low, compression, and a limiter. maybe there could be an option to turn it on or leave it off and the app will just use the preset one it always uses.

I agree this would be good. Even just a simple “cut low” slider and a “cut high” slider would be fantastic additions to the process. I see no reason why they didn’t include compression any longer with the drums in V5… so a return would be nice. As for a limiter, the one we have already has a field day most of the time, another one would make that even worse.

Read full topic
item.source: Sound quality question to Auxy EDMers, FBers, Bassheads, etc…

item.title: Sound quality question to Auxy EDMers, FBers, Bassheads, etc…
item.dc:creator: El1011
item.description:
I think its more of an Auxy limitation itself. While Auxy can def do harder type tracks, it’s still built around melodic type, more chill tracks. I feel like those tracks seems to sound better in Auxy than a hard hitting dubstep track in the app.

All in all, Auxy should implement a master/processing channel, even a basic one like the GB with high,med,low, compression, and a limiter. maybe there could be an option to turn it on or leave it off and the app will just use the preset one it always uses.

Read full topic

item.source: Sound quality question to Auxy EDMers, FBers, Bassheads, etc…

item.title: Sound quality question to Auxy EDMers, FBers, Bassheads, etc…
item.dc:creator: akabillposters
item.description:
I’m not sure that’s entirely true.
Auxy itself does quite a fair job of ‘mastering’.

It’s just that it’s all pointing to a single, ‘ideal’* dynamic profile.
(* according to the ideals of the dev team and their contributors)

Similarly, automated mastering is getting smarter all the time, and is, imo, already reaching ‘good enough’ levels of quality. (I’d say the days of human audio engineering are numbered, or at least, the numbers working in that industry will likely fall significantly over the next decade.)

Smart, AI-based automated mastering does indeed profile tracks individually and make adjustments accordingly, but they also tend to offer a range of profiles.

e.g. BandLab’s options are CD, Clarity or Bass Enhance, iirc.

Now, I’m not expecting the Auxy team to somehow create their own AI-based automated mastering into a £5/month app**, but perhaps a few other mastering profile presets would be possible.

A lot of this might be possible if we had per-instrument/kit compression, etc… controls.
(It comes back to that recurring request for a layer of ‘power’ tools for power-users.)

** Who knows, maybe it would be possible using API/hand-off to offer Auxy users the option to run their tracks through smarter, 3rd-party auto-mastering as part of the render/output process. Or maybe just offering a 3rd-party automated mastering site as an Export destination.

Read full topic
item.source: Sound quality question to Auxy EDMers, FBers, Bassheads, etc…

item.title: Sound quality question to Auxy EDMers, FBers, Bassheads, etc…
item.dc:creator: Zeph
item.description:
You can only achieve those things with engineering for that specific track, because every track is different. If it was simple to get a track to either have good dynamics or loudness, audio engineers wouldn’t exist.

Read full topic
item.source: Sound quality question to Auxy EDMers, FBers, Bassheads, etc…

item.title: Sound quality question to Auxy EDMers, FBers, Bassheads, etc…
item.dc:creator: TheRealJFalc
item.description:
Stigmo:

If this is mainly because I’m not capable of making it or because Auxy is too limited to make it, I don’t know. I think that it’s a bit of both.

It’s almost certainly a bit of both.

I’d say the best bet, if sticking directly to the Auxy presets alone, is doing the filtering, volume work, effects, etc. outside of Auxy. It seems to work rather well sometimes, but other times it gets really messy. The main issue when doing this is dealing with the limiter messing around with the tracks when exporting it. Setting the volume to 1/2-3/4 of the way up has, at least for me, worked sufficiently.

Read full topic
item.source: Sound quality question to Auxy EDMers, FBers, Bassheads, etc…

item.title: Sound quality question to Auxy EDMers, FBers, Bassheads, etc…
item.dc:creator: Stigmo
item.description:
I’ve tried to make this kind of stuff many, many times in Auxy, but I wasn’t able to even come close to it. If this is mainly because I’m not capable of making it or because Auxy is too limited to make it, I don’t know. I think that it’s a bit of both.

Read full topic
item.source: Sound quality question to Auxy EDMers, FBers, Bassheads, etc…

item.title: Sound quality question to Auxy EDMers, FBers, Bassheads, etc…
item.dc:creator: Db909
item.description:
No I get it. Setting levels properly is a big contributor to those qualities. I saw a lot of people mixing with filters primarily. That certainly carves space and makes things pop out more where they should, but you don’t get the same depth.

Volume gives the impression of a sound being closer or further away, where filtering is just going to affect the perception of the “size” of the sound, wherever it may be. So if it’s all filters, you may hear everything clearly, but it will all sound like a single 2d plane in front of your face with each sound crammed in there

Read full topic
item.source: Sound quality question to Auxy EDMers, FBers, Bassheads, etc…

item.title: Sound quality question to Auxy EDMers, FBers, Bassheads, etc…
item.dc:creator: akabillposters
item.description:
Perhaps I wasn’t clear.
It’s not the mix levels, per se. It’s the general ‘sound space’, the presence, the feel, the punch.

It just ‘sounds’ like a level of sonic finish that I don’t hear from Auxy producers.

Maybe it’s down to having more control over compression and stereo positioning, which electronic/EDM tracks often use quite heavily, but which Auxy users possibly don’t really have access to.

Read full topic
item.source: Sound quality question to Auxy EDMers, FBers, Bassheads, etc…

item.title: Sound quality question to Auxy EDMers, FBers, Bassheads, etc…
item.dc:creator: Db909
item.description:
I don’t think there’d be any problem getting that quality out of Auxy, providing you move the volume knob a bit. Back when you could frequently download features projects, I noticed many of them just left the faders at default. Which works out ok with Auxys engine, but it’s just close enough, not quite there. You can get really good mixes with setting levels alone so perhaps more of that in Auxy would result in better sonic quality

Read full topic

item.source: Sound quality question to Auxy EDMers, FBers, Bassheads, etc…

item.title: Sound quality question to Auxy EDMers, FBers, Bassheads, etc…
item.dc:creator: blakkaz
item.description:
akabillposters:

My immediate concern there would be that you’re seemingly forced to pick sounds for their sonic qualities rather than their character (if you know what I mean).

akabillposters:

But I’m wondering if the lack of control actually results in limited sonic options, and whether that ultimately makes Auxy outputs ‘uncompetitive’ in today’s sonic landscape.

This has been my biggest issue with solely using apps like Auxy.
I’ve always had strong opinions on how I want my music to sound and ‘close enough’ simply won’t do…

akabillposters:

In the absence of a small suite of mastering controls, I’m wondering if there’s a good argument for Auxy offering a range of ‘mastering’ presets, allowing creators to choose their own mastering emphasis.

I think this is a terrific idea.
I’d be surprised if this hasn’t at least been considered by Auxy HQ.

akabillposters:

I understand that Auxy is meant to be the app that shields users from the details for the sake of a smoother experience. It’s an admirable ethos.

I agree it’s admirable, but IMO it does put a ceiling on what Auxy can become.
For me, the studio has always been just another instrument.

https://www.ableton.com/en/blog/studio-as-an-instrument-part-1/
https://www.ableton.com/en/blog/studio-as-an-instrument-part-2/
https://www.ableton.com/en/blog/studio-as-an-instrument-part-3/
